steps.title: Turn off the electrical power supply and the fuel supply.
steps.content: Turn off the electrical power supply and the fuel supply. The electrical power supply will often be a switch on a red switch plate that is located at the top of the basement stairs or near the boiler. The fuel shutoff valve is either located near the oil tank (for oil boilers) or incoming gas pipe (for gas boilers). [2] X Research source You can also disconnect the power and fuel lines from the boiler. Place the end of the fuel line in a container to catch any fuel that may drip out of the line. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Let the boiler cool until it is cool to the touch.
steps.content: Let the boiler cool until it is cool to the touch. This is important to ensure your safety as you clean the boiler. Since it may take several hours to cool down, clean the boiler before heating season begins. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the nut on the combustion chamber door and open the door.
steps.content: Remove the nut on the combustion chamber door and open the door. The combustion chamber door is located on the front of the boiler. You may need to use a wrench to remove the nut. Place the nut somewhere secure so that you can easily locate it later. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Scrape the soot from the combustion chamber walls with a wire brush.
steps.content: Scrape the soot from the combustion chamber walls with a wire brush. Excess soot buildup can cause the boiler combustion chamber walls to corrode. Once the walls have been scraped clean, remove the soot with an industrial shop vac. [6] X Research source The combustion chamber is where the fuel mixes with air and is ignited to generate heat. Soot is a byproduct of this process. [7] X Research source Hardware stores often offer industrial shop vacs for rent. They are also available from construction supply rental companies.

steps.title: Change the air filter, if you have an oil-powered boiler.
steps.content: Change the air filter, if you have an oil-powered boiler. Close the oil valve, unscrew the oil filter, and replace it with a new one. The filter captures impurities that could clog the oil-burning nozzle and cause a misfire that shuts down the system. [8] X Research source Air filters can be purchased online or at a hardware store that stocks HVAC supplies. Follow local hazardous-waste regulations when disposing of the old filter. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Close the combustion chamber door and replace the nut.
steps.content: Close the combustion chamber door and replace the nut. Use a wrench to tighten the nut until it is firmly in place. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Reattach the power and fuel lines to the boiler if you disconnected them.
steps.content: Reattach the power and fuel lines to the boiler if you disconnected them. Turn the electrical power and fuel supply back on. Leave the fuel valve open until the fuel starts flowing to allow any air trapped in the fuel line to escape. [11] X Research source While the fuel valve is open, place a container under it to capture any excess fuel. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Check the temperature and pressure readings regularly.
steps.content: Check the temperature and pressure readings regularly. Boilers typically have gauges that monitor the boiler water temperature, circulating pump temperature, and pressure. Refer to the owner’s manual to make sure they are within correct limits. This will help you catch any potential problems. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Lubricate the circulating pump periodically.
steps.content: Lubricate the circulating pump periodically. The circulating pump is what moves the heated water from the boiler to the radiators, and is usually connected to a pipe near the boiler. Keeping it well-lubricated can prevent other system failures. Check the owner’s manual for guidance on how often to lubricate the circulating pump. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Check the water level in the expansion tank regularly.
steps.content: Check the water level in the expansion tank regularly. This is a small tank that protects the heating system from excessive pressure, and it should be about half full. If it is more than half full, open the expansion tank drain valve to return the tank to its correct level. [15] X Research source If tank begins to refill after a couple of days, consult an HVAC professional. There might be a leak or the air tank may need to be recharged. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Hire a professional to clean the burners, coils, draft hood, and chimney.
steps.content: Hire a professional to clean the burners, coils, draft hood, and chimney. Soot will build up in these areas even if the boiler is properly maintained. They need to be cleaned by a certified HVAC professional for safety reasons. [17] X Research source
